natural problem: What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\frac{x+6}{\sqrt{x^2-3x-4}}$?
natural solution: The function is defined when the value inside the square root is positive, i.e. we must have $x^2-3x-4>0$.
So either both factors in the left hand side are negative or they are both positive. They are both negative when $x<-1$. They are both positive when $x>4$.
So the domain of $f(x)$ is $x<-1 \text{ or } x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(-\infty, -1) \cup (4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = (x + 6) / sqrt (x powr 2 - 3 * x - 4)"
shows  "UNIV - {x. x \<le> -1 \<or> (-1 < x \<and> x < 4) \<or> 4 \<le> x} = {x. f x \<in> UNIV}"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\frac{x+6}{\sqrt{x^2-3x-4}}$? The final Answer is (-\infty, -1) \cup (4, \infty)
 ### Proof
 The function is defined when the value inside the square root is positive, i.e. we must have $x^2-3x-4>0$.
 Factoring, we get $(x-4)(x+1)>0$.
 So either both factors in the left hand side are negative or they are both positive. They are both negative when $x<-1$. They are both positive when $x>4$.
 So the domain of $f(x)$ is $x<-1 \text{ or } x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(-\infty, -1) \cup (4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = (x + 6) / sqrt (x powr 2 - 3 * x - 4)"
shows  "UNIV - {x. x \<le> -1 \<or> (-1 < x \<and> x < 4) \<or> 4 \<le> x} = {x. f x \<in> UNIV}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the domain of the function $f(x) = \frac{x + 6}{\sqrt{x^2 - 3x - 4}}$. The solution set is all real numbers except $x \leq -1$, $-1 < x < 4$, and $x \geq 4$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 6) / sqrt(x powr 2 - 3 * x - 4)"
shows  "x \<in> {y. y < -1} \<union> {y. y > 4}"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the domain of the function $f(x)=\frac{x+6}{\sqrt{x^2-3x-4}}$? The final Answer is (-\infty, -1) \cup (4, \infty)
 ### Proof
 The function is defined when the value inside the square root is positive, i.e. we must have $x^2-3x-4>0$.
 Factoring, we get $(x-4)(x+1)>0$.
 So either both factors in the left hand side are negative or they are both positive. They are both negative when $x<-1$. They are both positive when $x>4$.
 So the domain of $f(x)$ is $x<-1 \text{ or } x>4$, or $x \in \boxed{(-\infty, -1) \cup (4, \infty)}$ in interval notation.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 6) / sqrt(x powr 2 - 3 * x - 4)"
shows  "x \<in> {y. y < -1} \<union> {y. y > 4}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the range of $x$ for which the function $f(x) = \frac{x + 6}{\sqrt{x^2 - 3x - 4}}$ is defined. The final answer is $x < -1$ or $x > 4$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (x + 6) / sqrt(x powr 2 - 3 * x - 4)"
shows  "f x is defined \<Longrightarrow> x \<in> {-\<infinity>..-1} \<union> {4..\<infinity>}"

 *)
